content.description: Want to really blur the line between bouldering and free soloing? Look no further than this route on the south face of this behemoth. Once bolted (you can still see some of the holes), this is now a toprope/solo. The crux is probably in the first 15 feet, pulling between decent edges, but the scare factor only increases the higher you go as the rock quality decreases. Crank past the edges, climb up and slightly left past a hueco via somewhat crumbly rock, mantle onto the slab and forge ahead solidly into the 'no fall' zone. From here the route/problem is definitely not entirely over and some of the rock is highly suspect. Trend a bit left and continue up the slab. Tread lightly: the questionable rock makes this a pretty serious undertaking!
content.protection: Crash pads for the crux beginning and a cool head for the rest. It might be worth toproping this first as there was some dicey rock up high and the slab was more sustained than I was expecting. In fact, I would give this *** when climbed with a toprope.
content.location: This route is around the corner to the right of the steep face that holds the more renowned problems on the boulder. It starts on some hollow looking edges (stand on pads) and goes more or less straight up to a large hueco. From here, go up and left and mantle onto a large edge. Trend left and then more or less straight up. Downclimb the Advanced Rockcraft Arete.

content.description: Start with left hand on a high pinch and right hand on a lower small crimp and make a big hard move with the right hand to a high edge then top out with care...
content.protection: pads for the overhang, don't fall topping out

content.description: Sit-start to Rastaman Vibration. Start on a decent edge, move up to a shark tooth undercling/sidepull and a poor edge then make a big deadpoint to the start pinch on rastaman vibration and finish as for that problem. Extremely difficult
content.protection: Pads for the overhang. For the top out just don't fall

content.description: Tendons of steel and lots of core strength are needed for this weasel! Sit start with the right hand on a good edge and the left hand just under it. Pull on and move out to a left hand crimp rail. From here get a hand toe match and toe down like your life depends on it. Bring the right hand in then figure out a sequence that works best for you and traverse leftwards on improving holds before rounding the arete and dropping off from a jug. The problem eases up after the first 3 moves or so.
content.location: Starts sitting using the same holds as for "Lucid Dreaming" but traverses low and left.

content.description:
Stand start at the lowest good holds. Climb up and left onto some sharp crimps / holds. Dyno to the big crumbling jug out left. Make a few more hard and reachy moves to get established onto the slab. Keep climbing up the slab to the top.

Once you get established on the slab, the difficulty IMO is about 5.9ish. Most of the hands and feet are good, except for about 10-15 feet below the lip after a flake jug. The hands are slopey crimps and you have to stand up on less than ideal feet reaching for not so great hands. Fun.

Oh, don't fall.
content.location: The "route" is on the north face of the boulder.

climbs.name: Evilution to the Lip
climbs.fa: Chris Sharma did it to the lip Jason kehl linked it

content.description: Stand start on the pile of rocks nd reach up high to a good left hand incut crimp and a flat and slopey right hand crimp. Pull onto the wall and fire off a big intro move. This is the crux move, so latch it good and pt on the game face. Move in lefty before going up right hand agin. Once here, continue moving up and leftwards on increasing sized holds. Once on the good sidepull flake continue up and traverse the lip rightwards utilizing a good right hand undercling. Grab a sloper jug then jump down onto a double stack of pads.
content.protection: A minimum of 4 pads. The more the merrier.
content.location: On the front face of the giant Grandpa Peabody Boulder. This line is located almost smack in the middle of the giant overhang.

content.description:
This landmark problem was first climbed by Jason Kehl, and stands as a North American classic. At 55 feet, it is closer to a route than a boulder problem, and represents a new breed of boulder problems pushing the envelope of highball bouldering. The initial face was first ascended by Chris Sharma around the same time that he did 'The Mandala'. Originally, Chris simply dropped off from the lip holds at 20+ feet (most people down climb a bit before dropping). The initial face features steep patina crimps on immaculate rock streaked with yellow lichen. The drop-off problem is a classic in its own right and checks in at V9/10.

Jason's visionary line pulls the thin lip moves above the drop-off problem and continues onto an insecure 5.11 slab. The upper crux is purportedly V9. Since Jason's ascent, a variation has been established that takes a rightward exit that has easier moves, but on less than solid rock.
content.location: Center of the South face of the Grandpa Peabody.

content.description: Sit start at the large hold way down in the cave.  Make fun interesting moves out of the cave, until a large hold is reached.    Make a long reach up to a dish, match on this and grasp the bigger holds, then jump off.
content.location: First route round to the left of the major overhang.

content.description:
The stupid high gently overhanging face with the beautiful black streak on the Grandpa. Yeah so it's a boulder problem! V11 to the halfway point, then it supposedly eases up to V7 and then 5.12a

Enjoy!

Described by Dan Beal as, "The last king line in the buttermilks", The Process, FA'd by Daniel Woods, is the proudest and most obvious line on the classic Grandpa Peabody boulder in Bishop, CA. Starting as the rightmost line, it was the last portion of the overhanging face to be added to the list of hard climbs on the same wall: Lucid Dreaming, V15, and Evilution, V11.

The climb starts as a V12 crimp ladder, an over-the-head jump move, two V14 moves, and a V10 top out.
content.protection: Lots of pads and spotters. Don't fall over the lip.
content.location: The rightmost line of the Grandpa Peabody boulder overhanging face.

content.description: For many, this is the perfect highball. Located on the iconic Grandpa Peabody Boulder, the physical crux is, for most, pulling onto Grandpa from a smaller boulder. The mental crux for many is the last pull over on to the top. After getting established on Grandpa, traverse right and then shoot up via immaculate crimps. Incredible!
content.protection: If you're not solid at soloing 5.9, have a friend lead up to and set up a top rope. Most of the time it's done as a solo.
content.location: On the backside of the Granda Peabody boulder, to the right of Ambrosia. Scramble up a small boulder, then step from this to the Grandpa. Once established, traverse slightly right and then head up the slab. Follow the holds, take your time, and be careful to not get off-route. This is also the easiest down climb on the boulder.
